title: Micheldever Woods Walking Route

images.title: Sebastian Ballard, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Bluebells in the woods in early May

images.title: Andrew Smith / Micheldever Wood
images.caption: The main north-south track through the wood which is here a mixture of deciduous and coniferous trees.

images.title: Jim Champion / Bluebells near the edge of Micheldever Wood
images.caption: Bluebells near the edge of Micheldever Wood. Between the eastern boundary and the open beech woodland in Micheldever Wood is this region of dense silver birch growth. The bluebells are in profusion during May, and at the weekends people with cameras on tripods descend on the woods.

images.title: Jim Champion / Bluebells in Micheldever Wood
images.caption: Carpets of bluebells. This view is from atop the Bronze Age barrow on the western edge of the woods next to the M3 motorway. During May the bluebells carpet the floor of the beech woodland and the trees have grown new leaves.

images.title: Chris Talbot / Micheldever - The Crease
images.caption: Micheldever village. The Crease. This small triangle of grass is known as the crease.

images.title: Chris Talbot / Micheldever - Cottage Near The Crease
images.caption: Thatched cottage in the village.

images.title: Rosemary Oakeshott / St Mary's, Micheldever, churchyard
images.caption: The churchyard provides a magnificent view across the Dever valley, with the railway running across the horizon in the distance.

images.title: Rosemary Oakeshott / Half Moon & Spread Eagle, Micheldever
images.caption: Half Moon and Spread Eagle, Micheldever. The pub is in the Winchester Road, near the centre of the village. When a second pub in the village, the Spread Eagle, was burnt down its name was added to that of the Half Moon - hence the unusual name.

description: This walk explores Micheldever Woods near Basingstoke and Winchester. The woods are a lovely place for a peaceful stroll with the pretty bluebells in the spring a major attraction to the site. They are also particularly lovely in the autumn months when the leaves start to change colour. You can start your walk from the car park at the southern end of the woods, just off Northington Lane. It's located a couple of miles south east of Micheldever village. From here pick up the trails heading north into the woods where there are hundreds of acres to explore. You can extend the walk by heading into the adjacent Dodsley Wood to the north east or Itchen Wood to the south.
